Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Situation2: Savings are set aside and friends are going this season.
Story: I was finishing up a trim for Mrs. Lee, one of my favorite regulars, when she glanced in the mirror and smiled. “Could you just take a little more off the fringe?” she asked, her tone gentle. I nodded, reaching for my scissors, but my mind was elsewhere. My friends had just messaged me—they were booking their flights for Hajj this year. I’d been saving for months, setting aside every extra tip, dreaming of finally fulfilling this pillar of my faith. But the salon had been slow lately, and I knew that if I refunded Mrs. Lee for her last-minute change, or if she left unhappy, it could mean losing a loyal client and a chunk of my savings. My boss expected me to keep clients satisfied, no matter what. Yet, every riyal counted toward my pilgrimage. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing on me: the duty to my client, and the sacred call to Hajj. My hands hovered, scissors poised, as I tried to steady my breath, torn between the expectations of my profession and my faith.
